BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the often large wind slabs represent the main danger. It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 1800 m. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. They are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, this also applies at a distance from ridgelines. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are possible. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
As the snowfall becomes more intense numerous avalanches are possible, but they can be large.
From high-altitude starting zones the dry avalanches can reach a long way and in isolated cases endanger transportation routes situated at relatively high altitudes. With the onset of the intense snowfall, the natural avalanche activity will already appreciably increase.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places in particular on sunny slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is unstable; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow. The snowpack will become gradually prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: A lot of snow will fall. Even emptied starting zones will be replenished as a consequence of the snowfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the often large wind slabs represent the main danger. It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 1800 m. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. They are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, this also applies at a distance from ridgelines. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are possible. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
As the snowfall becomes more intense numerous avalanches are possible, but they can be large.
From high-altitude starting zones the dry avalanches can reach a long way and in isolated cases endanger transportation routes situated at relatively high altitudes. With the onset of the intense snowfall, the natural avalanche activity will already appreciably increase.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places in particular on sunny slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is unstable; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow. The snowpack will become gradually prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: A lot of snow will fall. Even emptied starting zones will be replenished as a consequence of the snowfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche danger will increase during the day. The fresh snow and the often large wind slabs represent the main danger. The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, snowfall the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop. Natural avalanches and dry and wet avalanches are possible from the afternoon. Many medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible, especially on very steep slopes at the base of rock walls. In the regions where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater.
In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes large natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected.
Weakly bonded old snow: Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on northwest, north and east facing slopes. These are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, this also applies at a distance from ridgelines. In particular slopes that have been little used this winter thus far are especially dangerous. Weak layers near the ground can be released by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Maintaining distances between individuals and one-at-a-time descents are recommended.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1800 m.
60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. The easterly wind has transported some snow. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The weather was cloudy. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches have been released as a consequence of warming.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals. Numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and wet avalanches have been released in the last two days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: The conditions are precarious for snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes. The danger of dry and wet avalanches will already exist in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche danger will increase during the day. The fresh snow and the often large wind slabs represent the main danger. The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, snowfall the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop. Natural avalanches and dry and wet avalanches are possible from the afternoon. Many medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible, especially on very steep slopes at the base of rock walls. In the regions where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater.
In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes large natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected.
Weakly bonded old snow: Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on northwest, north and east facing slopes. These are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, this also applies at a distance from ridgelines. In particular slopes that have been little used this winter thus far are especially dangerous. Weak layers near the ground can be released by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Maintaining distances between individuals and one-at-a-time descents are recommended.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1800 m.
60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. The easterly wind has transported some snow. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The weather was cloudy. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches have been released as a consequence of warming.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals. Numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and wet avalanches have been released in the last two days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: The conditions are precarious for snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes. The danger of dry and wet avalanches will already exist in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and gliding snow require caution. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night. The current avalanche situation calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Up to 1800 m rain fell yesterday. The moderate wind has transported the new snow. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
In the early morning as a consequence of solar radiation there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches for a short time, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially on very steep sunny slopes. Dry and moist avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large. Below approximately 2200 m medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in all aspects.
The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise. As before, it is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. Up to 1800 m rain has fallen since Wednesday. The sleet gave rise to significant settling of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: Further increase in avalanche danger as the snowfall becomes more intense.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche danger will increase during the day. The fresh snow and the often large wind slabs represent the main danger. The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, snowfall the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop. Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on little-used, rather lightly snow-covered northwest, north and east facing slopes. In particular transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack are especially dangerous. Weak layers near the ground can be released in some places by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Maintaining distances between individuals and one-at-a-time descents are recommended.
Natural avalanches: Some medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible, especially on very steep slopes at the base of rock walls. In the regions where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater.
Moist and wet avalanches and snow slides are still possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1800 m.
40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. The easterly wind has transported some snow. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The weather was cloudy. Medium-sized moist and wet avalanches have been released as a consequence of warming.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals. Stability tests and field observations confirm a precarious avalanche situation.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line. The wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
The snowpack remains prone to triggering in particular in extremely steep terrain. As a consequence of new snow and wind avalanches are to be expected, even large ones in isolated cases.
Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. During the night the weather was clear at times in some regions.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and has a loosely bonded surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon. In the regions where more snow falls the danger will increase more quickly.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow represent the main danger. In addition the wind slabs must be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More natural avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones, especially in steep rocky terrain, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. In steep gullies in the regions with a lot of snow the avalanches can in isolated cases reach low altitudes. Fresh wind slabs can in some cases be released easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are and are difficult to recognise. Gliding avalanches are also to be expected at any time. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some regions up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Friday above approximately 2000 m. Little snow will fall on Saturday in some localities. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers especially on steep shady slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind and new snow above approximately 1400 m. In some localities up to 20 cm of snow will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The weather conditions gave rise to softening of the snowpack.
Over a wide area precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. In steep rocky terrain and adjacent to ridgelines more moist and wet snow slides are possible. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
Even single winter sport participants can release avalanches. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The snowpack remains generally moist. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Unexpected weather pattern: Some snow will fall over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow, wind slabs and old snow represent the main danger. Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for very extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the new snow natural avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases, especially on steep slopes. In steep gullies in the regions with a lot of snow the avalanches can reach intermediate altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches easily. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in steep terrain above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint. Below approximately 2600 m small and medium-sized gliding avalanches and snow slides are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Friday above approximately 1700 m. The fresh snow as well as the often deep wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. Below approximately 1300 m hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1500 m. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The weather conditions gave rise to softening of the snowpack.
Over a wide area precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur at any time. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches as before.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular in the north a lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The snowpack remains generally moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Unexpected weather pattern: Some snow will fall over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can in isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size.

More frequent wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area up to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Friday. In some regions up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day.

As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs will increase in size. They are in some cases prone to triggering, in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Monday. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size.
Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Backcountry touring calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on little-used, rather lightly snow-covered northwest, north and east facing slopes. In particular transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack are especially dangerous. Weak layers near the ground can be released in some places by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
Natural avalanches: Moist and wet avalanches are still possible, after an overcast night especially on steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
40 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday.
The easterly wind has transported some snow. Numerous medium-sized moist and wet avalanches have been released as a consequence of warming. 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall on Saturday.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches. Fresh wind slabs at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More frequent wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.

The wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 10 cm of snow fell on Friday. Some snow will fall on Saturday in some regions.
The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day.

Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. This applies at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides require caution.
Over a wide area up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Monday. In isolated cases the wind slabs will increase in size.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day. Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More frequent wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.

The wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow fell on Friday.
The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day.

Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. This applies at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides require caution.
Some snow will fall until Monday. In isolated cases the wind slabs will increase in size.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Mostly small avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep slopes especially above approximately 1600 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. Below approximately 1600 m a little snow is lying. At high altitude the avalanche danger is a little higher.
